awd_titl_txt: Practicing Radical Innovation in Manufacturing Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing is an emerging advanced technological field that uses a set of technologies, such as 3D printing, to make products based on a digital model. Additive manufacturing is a valuable tool in many industries, including defense, aerospace, automotive, medical or dental, and metal manufacturing industries. Workers with skills in advanced technologies are in high demand in the nation's technical workforce. The inclusion of additive manufacturing in technical education programs helps prepare technicians to meet the demand. Effective instruction in this new technology requires careful consideration of best practices for course design and enhancing student learning. In this project, Green River Community College will update its manufacturing courses and adopt an instructional approach that lets students demonstrate the skills they have learned. The instructional approach involves experts from industry who judge how well students have mastered the skills for use on the job. The project will contribute to growing the STEM workforce by educating students for thriving technical careers in additive manufacturing.  

The goals of this project at Green River Community College are to enhance the instruction of future technicians and to produce diverse, well-qualified graduates for the STEM technical workforce. Project activities will include research-based practices such as industry-based curricula and authentic assessment. The project will: 1) Integrate core competencies in additive manufacturing identified by the National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education into existing courses; 2) Develop the long-term capacity of faculty to conduct, assess, and refine instruction in additive manufacturing; 3) Develop and test the effectiveness of authentic assessment models for continuous course and program improvement, so that instruction remains technically relevant with modern industry techniques, applications, equipment, and methods; and 4) Provide workshops on the use of the authentic assessment approach for faculty in other STEM technical programs. The project?s authentic assessment approach builds on a model developed and implemented by the Community Colleges of Spokane over the last fifteen years. The distinctive feature of this model is the integration of industry experts as volunteer examiners to ensure consistency between the assessment and the real-world applications for which students are being prepared. The project will also align the updated courses with the statewide, industry-based, Core Plus high school curriculum to promote pathways for students in this technology field. Results from the project will be widely disseminated with the aid of industry, educational, and state governmental partners.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The project tested the use of industry-based “authentic assessment” techniques, in partnership with local employers and a K-12 school district. Their work was documented in an assessment form that may be reused and adapted for use by other manufacturing educational programs. It mimics the real-world industry practice when an authorized person - typically a supplier or a second-party inspector with a laboratory and specialized measuring equipment - takes one or several parts from a production run and compares them to a client’s specifications to verify that they precisely match. Project faculty attended trainings conducted by an NSF ATE resource center, the Online Instructional Resources for Material Science Technology Education (MatEdU), to learn how to teach using techniques such as virtual reality simulations. Faculty worked with MatEdU to produce reference materials for STEM educators on topics such as how to recycle and reuse waste generated by 3-D printers, which saves money and reduces additive manufacturing’s environmental impact. Faculty collaborated with non-STEM programs to explore diverse instructional applications of additive manufacturing techniques: for example, simulating open wounds and similar physical injuries for Nursing students, or prototypes of new products designed by Marketing & Entrepreneurship students for them to demonstrate in juried “shark tank” competitions. When the COVID-19 pandemic struck, faculty used this knowledge to design, manufacture, and distribute life-saving personal protective equipment used by local medical, EMS, and Life-Flight Northwest front line workers.

Broader Impacts: Three new courses on additive manufacturing were created and added to the existing Associate degree program in Mechanical Computer-Aided Design: Fundamentals of Additive Manufacturing, Intermediate Additive Manufacturing, and Advanced Additive Manufacturing. Associate degree students may now earn a nine-credit certificate in Additive Manufacturing Technology as part of their degree. This prepares them for entry into industry as Level 1 or 2 Additive Manufacturing system operators with prominent local STEM employers, such as Blue Origin Aerospace Company. Current employees of manufacturing businesses may also take these courses separately, if they want to update or expand their skills by mastering the use of contemporary systems such as multi-axis 3-D printers. The project upgraded its additive manufacturing classroom with equipment funded from other sources to facilitate instruction. Project faculty shared data and sample materials at professional conferences for STEM educators: for example, the High Impact Technology Exchange Conference. STEM industry representatives subsequently toured the additive manufacturing classroom, which inspired an ongoing discussion about how to leverage it to up-skill their current employees. Project personnel collaborated with the University of Washington's Materials Science and Engineering department to exchange information about their respective educational programs, inform the project’s curriculum, and raise Associate-level students’ awareness of options for their continuing education.

 


Last Modified: 01/06/2023
Modified by: Bradley Chinn
